thread.title: TCU's Gary Patterson: Defensive end's legal problem 'not even close' to what happened at Baylor
thread.title_full: TCU's Gary Patterson: Defensive end's legal problem 'not even close' to what happened at Baylor | Dallas Morning News

author: Eddie Sefko
title: TCU's Gary Patterson: Defensive end's legal problem 'not even close' to what happened at Baylor
text:
FORT WORTH -- TCU coach Gary Patterson on Tuesday stood up for a senior leader on his football team.
In the process, he no doubt ruffled feathers 90 miles south in Waco.
Patterson was assessing the situation that involves Mike Tuaua, a defensive end who has been suspended since Sept. 7 after being arrested Sept. 4 on charges of robbery with bodily injury, a second-degree felony.
Patterson, during his weekly news conference, made a strong assertion that Tuaua's problems are not nearly as serious as the sexual assault case that happened at Baylor before the start of this football season.
Tuaua was dismissed from the Horned Frogs football team after the incident in which he allegedly beat up another TCU student and stole a case of beer. Tuaua and freshman receiver Andre Petties-Wilson posted bond, and Patterson said he is waiting for the facts to play out.
But his reference to Baylor did nothing but add fuel to a fiery rivalry that has escalated quickly between two of the top-five ranked teams in the country.
"All I care [about] is a 50-50 deal," Patterson said at his weekly news conference. "In this kid's case, Mike Tuaua, we'll find out what the facts are. It'll all come out. I just hope when they all come out, you report it just as strongly as what you've done here because it's not even close to what happened south of here."
That was an obvious reference to the Baylor case involving Sam Ukwuachu, who was convicted of sexually assaulting a fellow student after having had a tainted past at Boise State before transferring to Baylor.
Patterson's comparison immediately drew wide criticism on social media.
The coach added that Tuaua had suffered a partially torn ligament before the season opener against Minnesota, the only game in which he has played this season. He started five games last season and was viewed as a foundation piece of the defense coming into the season and as such was named a captain by Patterson.
Patterson said that a decision would have had to be made this week on whether Tuaua would redshirt because of the injury. But that is a moot point until the legal issue is resolved. Injuries have decimated the Frogs on the defensive side of the ball.
The coach also said that Tuaua will not play for the Frogs until the legal process is complete.
After comparing the situation to the one in Waco, Patterson came to the defense of his player.
"I'm just going to tell you something right now when it comes to Mike Tuaua," Patterson said. "I named him captain, but outside [of football] in our community, with kids, he's the most-liked kid we have on our team beside [quarterback] Trevone Boykin."
Patterson said he's willing to let the situation play out. He was hopeful that it would be addressed by the school last week, but it wasn't.
"I'm just telling you, as far as just a person, I'm not going to let you say this kid's a bad person," Patterson said. "If he made a mistake, he made a mistake, OK? "
Patterson went on to say that in his 15 years at TCU he has never felt compelled to stick up for a player involved in controversy.
"There's a bunch of stuff I can't talk about," Patterson said. "My job is the football coach. But I would say this. When we've had things go on, you've never heard me ever speak up for a kid if he screwed up. But you did now."
The legal problem, which didn't become public until two weeks after Tuaua was suspended, for the moment has overshadowed what will be TCU's stiffest test of the season Saturday at Texas Tech (3-0).
